content.definition: A rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by multiple cutaneous and visceral venous malformations that appear as compressible blue-purple nodules resembling rubber nipples. The syndrome involves characteristic lesions on skin and throughout the gastrointestinal tract, leading to chronic occult bleeding and iron-deficiency anemia.

cutaneous: Variable size from mm to several cm
Present at birth or appear in childhood
gastrointestinal: Lesions throughout GI tract (small bowel most common)

pathophysiology.etiology: Sporadic somatic mutations in TEK gene (encoding TIE2 receptor)
pathophysiology.inheritance: Usually sporadic; rare familial cases (autosomal dominant)
pathophysiology.mechanism: Abnormal venous endothelial cell proliferation and vessel formation

diagnosis.endoscopy: Multiple venous malformations in GI tract
diagnosis.histology: Dilated venous channels with thin walls, no smooth muscle

interventional: Surgical resection for localized GI disease

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic appearance of BRBNS cutaneous lesions
Understand the association with GI bleeding and anemia
Know the management options for symptomatic disease
clinical_pearls: Lesions are compressible and refill - distinguishes from other vascular lesions
GI bleeding is typically chronic and occult rather than acute
Small bowel is most commonly affected GI segment
Sirolimus shows promise as systemic therapy
common_misconceptions: Not all venous malformations syndromes cause GI bleeding - BRBNS specifically involves GI tract
